lineItems.title: Forms
lineItems.html: Forms provide a strong baseline for how your product works visually and programmatically. Even if none of the forms are exposed to users, writing down your forms can provide your developers with a complete picture of your desired data and how to best store and retrieve it.

lineItems.title: Startup Data
lineItems.html:
Try to use realistic data rather than Latin or jumbled placeholders.

Use shutterstock.com or other licensing tool to find quality graphics and photography with proper licensing.

lineItems.title: Objects
lineItems.html: For this site, we have 6 primary 'objects': Rallies, Meetings, Resources, Invites, Officials, Cities

lineItems.title: Actions
lineItems.html:
Consider Actions as the things a typical user can do, not what your entire system can do. Examples include:

Create/Add, Read/View, Update/Edit, Delete/Unpublish


Also maybe "add to cart", "checkout", "like/unlike", ...

lineItems.title: Data
lineItems.html:
"Data" is everything including scraped, user-generated, and curated content. 

  • Vocabularies (aka taxonomies) supports filtering searches
  • Permissions matrix supports security and error handling
  • Field schema describes how your Objects and fields all relate.

lineItems.title: Google Forms for predefined Data
lineItems.html: Using Google Forms - or any CMS you're familiar with - to digitizing your startup data and vocabulary terms.
